find.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.

Top-3 Similar Questions: au_359358: Can't connect to with TP-LINK USB wifi
Top-3 Scripts:
au_359358: sudo -i
echo "blacklist ath9k" >> /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf
modprobe -r ath9k
exit

Explanations about Options.-r:
This option causes modprobe to remove rather than insert a module. If the modules it
 depends on are also unused, modprobe will try to remove them too. Unlike insertion,
 more than one module can be specified on the command line (it does not make sense to
 specify module parameters when removing modules).
